The NHS Blood Drive is coming to the St. Ambrose Hall in seven days. We would like to thank everyone that has taken the time to register for a donation time. Your generosity has been overwhelming. The staff at the Mississippi Valley Regional Blood Center is so thankful to all of you as their blood supply desperately needs to be replenished.

To help expedite your time at the drive, we are encouraging everyone to utilize the Early Q application that allows you to answer the medical questions the day of the drive. Attached is an information flier about this process and the steps you can go through to either print the responses or to have available on your phone. This is not necessary- you can do the same medical questions when you arrive for your appointment.

Again, the NHS thanks the community for your support and generosity at giving the gift of blood. One pint helps three individuals.

EP Panther Football
April 13 at 4:57 PM ·

Noticed that Prophetstown will be lighting up their athletic fields tonight at 8:20 for 20 minutes to honor this years senior athletes who have seen a season get cancelled or postponed. Thought this was a fantastic idea, so we’re jumping on board. The Erie football field will (hopefully) be lit up tonight. Athletics might not seem like an important thing now, but the loss of connection, togetherness, and support that many young adult athletes usually get from their teammates and coaches is very real and is missing. Hopefully simply gestures like this can remind those athletes that hope is real, good times are on the horizon, and sports will happen again.

post_text: Mrs. Wall's Biology 1 class studying proteins called antigens on red blood cells that determine blood type (unless the person is O or negative rH). Mississippi Valley Regional Blood Center brought representatives to blood type students that were interested in finding out their blood type. They took three drops of blood and dropped a different serum on each. If the blood clumped on the serum, then it was a positive result. In the sample slide in the photos the student was positive for A, negative for B and positive for the rH factor. That means they have A+ blood type!!

In January, Mr. Armstrong’s 8th Grade History classes learned about the U.S. Constitution. Besides just learning about how the government works, they’ve also had guests from the area come in, to show how different topics apply to the real world.

-After learning about the Judicial Branch, Sydney Stubblefield, an Erie grad, came in to talk about how different court cases work and what her job is like as a lawyer.
-While learning about the Bill of Rights, our School Resource Officer/Erie Police Officer, Jessica Adams, came in to talk about how the rights spelled out in the Bill of Rights come into play for us in the real world, and about her job as a police officer.
-In learning about the role of the news and media, the creator of AroundPtown.com, Dan Eyrich, came in to talk about his experiences as a journalist, and what he tries to do with the website he started.

Wish the 8th graders good luck as their unit wraps up and they take the U.S. Constitution test soon!
